strTitle: Trigger for the Merga Plot Start Beat
strDesc: [us] senses disturbances near Venus.

strTitle: Trigger for the Merga Plot Start Beat
strDesc: [us] senses disturbances near Venus.

strTitle: Trigger for the Merga Plot Start Beat
strDesc: [us] senses disturbances near Venus.

strTitle: Trigger for the Merga Plot Start Beat
strDesc: [us] senses disturbances near Venus.

strTitle: Trigger for the Merga Plot Start Beat
strDesc: [us] senses disturbances near Venus.
[us] receives a strange call from Ursula K. pointing us to meet a detective on Venus named [3rd].

Ursula K. says she noticed [us] was looking closely into black handprint deaths and Camellia Middlemist case. They're connected and Detective [3rd] knows more. You should visit the Detective in a bar on Encantado aerostat called the Sol Vermelho Lounge. If you can't get a ship downwell to the aerostat, you can take the PASS system from the Venus Orbital (VORB).

strTitle: Trigger for advancing to Merga Plot's Signs Discussed Beat
strDesc: [us] begins investigating the Middlemist case. Start by visiting suspects (around Encantado) then check their alibis.

strTitle: Trigger for advancing to Merga Plot's Merga Engaged Beat
strDesc: [us] has gathered clues to a Middlemist suspect. Take the findings to the Detective

strTitle: Trigger for advancing to Merga Plot's Merga Known Beat
strDesc: [us] has risked harm to engage products of a deeper truth.

strTitle: Trigger for advancing to Merga Plot's Endgame Prepared Beat
strDesc: [us] has collected and prepared a Endgame related to a deeper truth.

strTitle: Trigger for advancing to Merga Plot's Endgame Completed Beat
strDesc: [us] has met a conclusion of a deeper truth.

strTitle: Trigger for advancing to Merga Plot's End Beat
strDesc: [us] has ended the Merga plot.
[us] watches [them] more closely and learns about the disappearance of Camellia Middlemist, a famous lounge singer from Venus.
strTooltip: Pay more attention to the news to learn details about a beloved entertainer missing from Venus.

strDesc: [them] learns that Camellia Middlemist, aka Miss M, went missing without a trace, creating a major media sensation in and around Venus. Her spouse, a champion Encantado circuit racer, has been brought in for questioning by authorities.

[us] watches [them] more closely and learns about a mysterious string of deaths in the OKLG region and beyond. Apparently spacers are being found deceased with no obvious cause beyond a blackened handprint on their body.
strTooltip: Pay more attention to the news to learn details about a strange string of deaths.

strDesc: [them] finds more coverage of the strange deaths. In addition to the necrotized skin tissue in the shape of a hand with inhumanly long fingers, many of the victims appear to be loners and outcasts. In one case, a victim's entire residence had been ransacked, and certain storage drives were stolen.
Another one of those bodies was found with the black handprint on their body, this time around Venus. Was it that missing celebrity? Damndest thing...

I can't stop thinking about Miss M going missing from her home on Encantado aerostat, over on Venus? My money says [3rd] had something to do with it. I don't care how many Grande Prêmio races they've nabbed. That one is shady.
[us] watches [them] more closely and learns about Venusian racing icon [3rd], and their recent scandals.

Phenom RCS racer [3rd] won a record fourth Grande Prêmio do Encantado this week. Suspicion and intrigue surround the otherwise joyous occasion as the racer's spouse, lounge singer Camellia Middlemist, remains missing.
[us] discusses with [them] news and rumors surrounding the fate of a Venusian entertainer.
[us] grumbles to [them] about the loss of productivity in their work force since Miss M's dissappearance. It's like nobody wants to work anymore...

[us] assures [them] that local authorities are investigating, so no need to panic. Sure the circumstances are strange, and everybody loved them, but any perpetrators will be found and punishment will follow.

[us] gladly gossips with [them] about the missing celebrity, including salacious rumors about foul play, superstitious possible causes, and personal stories of relationships with them before they died.

strTitle: Ask for Theories on Camellia Middlemist
strDesc: [us] asks [them] for their current theory on where the missing lounge singer might be.
[us] says they try not to pay attention to the tabloid rags.
[us] says they've seen people go missing before. After 72 hours, you should probably assume the worst.

strTitle: Discuss first Theory on Missing Celeb
strDesc: [us] enthusiastically replies with an elaborate tale involving a conspiracy between Middlemist's spouse, a famous RCS racer, and the man who owns the club where she sings.

strTitle: Discuss second Theory on Missing Celeb
strDesc: [us] says they have been watching concert splices made by someone who seems legitimately unhinged. They insist this person is somehow involved.

strTitle: Discuss third Theory on Missing Celeb
strDesc: [us] read on a forum that Middlemist was having an affair with someone in law enforcement. They also insist she is a clone.

strTitle: Discuss fourth Theory on Missing Celeb
strDesc: [us] says Middlemist probably couldn't handle the attention and ran off. She's done it before, after all.

strTitle: Express Personal Theory on Camellia Middlemist
strDesc: [us] describes their current theory on where the missing lounge singer might be to [them].
[us] listens to [them]'s theory and adds details to support the possibility.
[us] listens closely, and offers several crucial details that contradict and challenge [them]'s theory.

strTitle: Ask for Theories on the Black Hand Deaths
strDesc: [us] asks [them] their theory as to why people keep turning up dead with black handprints on their bodies.
[us] insists it is just a rumor. People wind up dead all the time around here.
[us] says that is meant to be privileged information, and suggests you don't talk about it anymore.
[us] says there is a pattern to the victims, and anyone who looks close enough will find it.
[us] glances around the room and starts to say something before waving you off.
[us] says Ayotimiwa has to be involved somehow.
[us] says their grandfather saw something like this before, back on Earth.

strTitle: Express Personal Theory on Black Hand Deaths
strDesc: [us] describes their current theory to [them], regarding the bodies turning up dead on OKLG with black hand prints on them.
[us] listens to [them]'s theory and adds details to support the possibility.
[us] listens closely and offers several crucial details that contradict and challenge [them]'s theory.
[us] asks Detective [them] about the six major suspects in the Middlemist case
Detective [us] offers information on the six main suspects in the Middlemist case. "Take some notes, kid."
[us] asks Detective [them] about the racing icon.

Detective [us] says that one major suspect is [3rd], a five-time Grande Prêmio do Encantado winner and Middlemist's current spouse. Their tumultuous relationship is the subject of many a tabloid reel.
[us] asks Detective [them] about the journalist.
Detective [us] describes that [3rd] produces a rumor rag that is wildly popular, especially in NewCal. Middlemist has been their sole subject since the case began.
[us] asks Detective [them] about the Superfan
Detective [us] says that [3rd] is absolutely obsessed with Miss M and appeared at nearly every show until Middlemist put out a restraining order against them.
[us] asks Detective [them] about Mogul
Detective [us] says that [3rd] is a prominent business exec on Encantado who owns, among many other things, the lounge where Miss M used to sing.
[us] asks Detective [them] about ex-cop

Detective [us] says that Josephus Tanner is their former partner, someone who went off the deep end chasing down leads for a strange case. For reasons they don't fully understand, Middlemist recently became a part of that investigation.
[us] asks Detective [them] about Middlemist

Detective [us] says the famous singer Camellia Middlemist, Miss M, was recently found dead in her green room at the Sol Vermelho Lounge on Encantado. There was a black handprint on her lower back but otherwise no clear cause of death.
[us] says they'll think further on this. Next, Detective [them] advises talking to suspects and checking their alibis.
[us] asks [them] where they were the night Middlemist went missing.
[us] says they were blackout drunk with their buddies celebrating their recent threepeat Grande Prêmio do Encantado win.
[us] leans hard on [them], threatening all kinds of harm if they don't start talking.
[us] says folks from Venus don't scare easy and that maybe [them] should head back to the dark corner they crawled out of on OKLG.
[us] shrinks away and says the person to look into is officer Josephus Tanner. He couldn't stay away from her before she disappeared.
[us] speaks softly to [them], making them feel like a friend before asking what else they know about the night Miss M disappeared.
[us] smiles and says that before M went missing she was being followed around by officer Josephus Tanner.
[us] scowls and says they don't have any reason to talk to a stranger from OKLG.
[us] asks [them] where they were the night Middlemist went missing.
[us] flashes a strange grin, and says they were at home editing video of Middlemist's recent performances that night.
[us] says they are a fan [them]'s reels and asks if they can see the one made that night.

[us] eagerly retrieves their PDA and shows [them] a montage of shaky cam footage set to bubbly pop music. One shot stands out: [3rd] leaving Encantado on the night of their most recent Grande Prêmio win. They step soberly into their racer, undock, and dart nimbly into the clouds.

[us] says they've never seen you in the comments and then retrieves their PDA. The video is a montage of shaky cam footage set to bubbly pop music. One shot stands out: [3rd] leaving Encantado on the night of their most recent Grande Prêmio win. They step soberly into their racer, undock, and dart nimbly into the void.
[us] plays the bad cop card and tries to intimidate [them] into showing the reel.

[us] quickly retrieves their PDA and shows [them] a montage of shaky cam footage set to bubbly pop music. One shot stands out: [3rd] leaving Encantado on the night of their most recent Grande Prêmio win. They step soberly into their racer, undock, and dart nimbly into the void.

[us] says they don't scare easy but is always happy to have a new fan. They show a montage of shaky cam footage set to bubbly pop music. One shot stands out: [3rd] leaving Encantado on the night of their most recent Grande Prêmio win. They step soberly into their racer, undock, and dart nimbly into the void.
[us] asks [them] where they were the night Middlemist went missing.
[us] says they were out to dinner with their Lead Counsel at a prominent NewCal restaurant that night.
[us] asks [them] where they were the night Middlemist went missing.

[them ] says they were at the office in NewCal interviewing the lead counsel representing the owner of the Sol Vermelho Lounge for an upcoming story about race fixing. The interview was several hours long and video taped.
[us] finds a deep purple residue seemingly burned into the bartop in front of [3rd]'s favorite bar seat.

[us] uses the LEO login to track [3rd]'s location. On the night of Middlemist's disappearance local networks pinged them all over San Diego making what appears to be repeat visits to different shops in the area.
[us] asks [them] if they remember seeing [3rd] on the night in question.
[us] says they see so many people in a day there's no way they could remember someone like that.
[us] says they wish they could help but they didn't see anyone who matches that description.
[us] appears annoyed at the intrusion and says they are very confident that person didn't come their shop that day.
[us] says actually yes. A disturbed seeming person returned many times to purchase high end electronics that night.
[us] remembers them well. They purchased three pairs of expensive heels in a very particular size and had them all gift wrapped.
[us] says yes. This person was extremely sweaty and bought evening wear and lingerie from the private stock.
[us] gazes into the distance and recalls a person of this description asking what the most expensive thing in stock was. They couldn't afford it and left very, very angry.
Oh yes, [us] remembers. Someone matching this description kept demanding to see the most expensive thing in the store. They then asked if the item would appeal to a woman with discerning taste.
[us] asks [them] if they can present evidence on a certain suspect in the Middlemist case.
[us] finishes up presenting evidence, for now.

strTitle: Ask Who They Want to Hear About
strDesc: [us] asks who [them] has evidence on.
[us] offers [them] the evidence gathered so far to support the famous racing icon as the potential killer of Camellia Middlemist.
[us] says you don't have much. Try pressing them for an alibi as a start.
[us] says being three sheets after a win like that is reasonable enough. If they were that drunk somebody would have seen it. We should ask around.

Detective [us] says the footage is certainly suspicious. Try confronting them about it. The racer is also a constant presence in the Sol Vermelho Lounge center bar. Maybe looking around there will yield more information.
[us] says they've heard enough. They are going to examine the bar and then together you can confront the racer.
[us] offers [them] the evidence gathered so far to support the famous racing icon as the potential killer of Camellia Middlemist.
[us] offers [them] the evidence gathered so far to support the superfan as the potential killer of Camellia Middlemist.
[us] says you don't have much. Try pressing them for an alibi as a start.

[us] says the video isn't proof they were home all night. Besides, being at home is hardly an alibi. The detective gives [them] login credentials for LEO software and says to use any terminal to check the superfans network access point log data to get a sense of where they were that night.
[us] says the next step is obviously retracing the superfan's moves that night. Go to San Diego and talk to the shopkeepers there to see if they remember seeing anyone suspicious.
[us] says this is suspicious enough to at least have a hard chat with the superfan. Together you find and confront them.
[us] offers [them] the evidence gathered so far to support the Journalist as the potential killer of Camellia Middlemist.

strTitle: Offer Evidence on Detective Josephus Tanner
strDesc: [us] offers [them] the evidence gathered so far to support Detective Josephus Tanner the potential killer of Camellia Middlemist.
It's always the spouse. With associates in the Briar Rose and money to spare, [racing_icon] certainly has the means to kill Middlemist. But why would they risk their reputation so publicly?
XXX
XXX
[racing_icon] almost certainly lied about their alibi, as they were likely sober on the night of Middlemist's disappearance. But where were they going in such a hurry?
[us] shows [them] the footage [3rd] made of the racing icon sober on the night of Middlemist's disappearance and asks why they would lie about being drunk.
[us] says [3rd] is a nosy little freak. Besides, the footage doesn't prove they were sober. They've always been able to hold their liquor.
[us] asks [them] why they lied, and why they made so many visits to the shops in San Diego on the might of Miss M's disappearance.
[them] giggles and speaks at length about how there's nothing they love more than shopping.
XXX
XXX
XXX
XXX
XXX
XXX
Together you leave to confront the suspect.
Together you leave to confront the suspect.

You find the superfan and grill them about the footage you found. It's a strange interrogation at first. Every question and demand is met with a giggle or coy smile, no matter how serious the matter at hand.

Maybe sensing an angle, your detective partner lays on the bad cop act, lacing their tone with parental admonishments and scolding. The dam breaks. In an instant the superfan's eerie smile melts into an expression of childish rage and confusion.

"He promised," the superfan manages through bitter tears. "He promised to make her love me."

"Who promised?"

"The cloaked one. With hollow eyes."

"I need you to tell me exactly what he said."

"He said if I told him where Miss M was that night that he would give her the gifts I bought her. That she wouldn't refuse them anymore. That she would take me instead of that awful cop she was always with."

"What cop," the detective asks.

"You know what cop," the superfan replies. "Your little friend. Tanner."

"And if he couldn't? Couldn't convince her?"

 "He promised," the superfan tries. "That he would make her pay. For choosing Tanner instead of me. Oh god I'm so sorry…"

The superfan breaks into racking sobs and continues pleading the detective and Miss M for forgiveness for what they've done.

You cuff the sniveling superfan and take them in for processing.

You lead with the suspect's access to the victim and failed alibi and leave out their crazed tale of the cloaked accomplice. It's more than enough to convince the upper LEO brass and with the entire system begging for a head to roll in the case, you're certain the NewCal DA will convict without much difficulty.

News of your work on the case circulates quickly among the ranks of the Venusian police. After a meeting with a handful of the department upper brass, you're assured that if you ever find yourself in trouble with the law in and around Venus, it will turn out to be no trouble at all. 

When the dust settles the detective thanks you for your help and offers their assistance if you ever need it in the future.

"One more thing," they say before you leave. "What our suspect said about the cloaked figure reminds me of something Josephus Tanner told me about when he was at his worst. Come with me. We should tie up one last loose end."

Together you lead the blubbering superfan through non trafficked maintenance corridors towards the LA Aerostat, ignoring their pleas all the way. As you do so you're met with the uncanny feeling that this is something your detective friend has done before. 

You reach an abandoned garbage airlock and stuff the superfan inside. There's a brief moment when you wonder who will open the trap door on the other side. You suddenly realize it doesn't matter. You press the button to open the floor and the sniveling accomplice to murder falls to their certain death through Venus's sulfurous, caustic fog.

The detective turns to you with a look in their eyes you've never seen before.

"You're mine now," they say. "Forever. Whatever I ask of you. No questions. When I say jump, you say how high. And if you ever speak of this to anyone, you'll find yourself begging for the mercy we just showed that scumbag. 

Lastly, you'll need this. For when shit hits the fan."

The detective hands you a briefcase. You're surprised by how heavy it is and wonder what could be inside.

"First order of business: what our suspect said about the cloaked figure reminds me of something Josephus Tanner told me about when he was at his worst. Come with me."

You find the racing icon sipping Cachaca and lime in a dark corner of the Sol Vermelho Lounge. He raisees the glass to you as you approach. 

"Rare Earth vintage," he says. "Might be the last bottle in the System."

"Lime ain't cheap, either," the detective mutters. 

"So?" the racer asks. "This better be quick. I have a shuttle headed to Hangzhou in an hour."

You tell him about the false alibi, how nobody could fly like that while drunk, even them.

"Proves nothing," the racer says before taking a sip. "She died with a handprint like the rest of them."

"Faked," the detective says. "Checked the body an hour ago. Whatever you used to stain it on matches what we found all over your favorite seat here in the bar. I'm sure we'll find traces of it in your ship when we seize it tonight."

The racing icon stares at you for a long moment, drains his drink, then looks up at the stage.

"This is where we fell in love, you know" they say. "She was singing Mas Que Nada."

"Why, then?" you ask. "Why kill her?"

The racer wheels towards the detective, tears of rage welling in his eyes. 

"Why don't you ask your partner, you son of a bitch?"

"Tanner?"

"Pigs," the racer scoffs. "You're all the same. Think everything in the world belongs to you."

The racing icon wipes his eyes and takes a long look at the detective. "But I have a feeling Tanner isn't going to be much of a problem to anyone anymore.

You cuff Korin and take him in for processing. Sure enough, a material analysis of his champion racing vessel yields trace amounts of the same compound stained on Middlemist's hip. It's not a job he could have done alone, but even without accomplices, the evidence is enough to put the champion racer away for a long time.

News of your work on the case circulates quickly among the ranks of the Venusian police. After a meeting with a handful of the department upper brass, you're assured that if you ever find yourself in trouble with the law in and around Venus, it will turn out to be no trouble at all.

When the dust settles the detective thanks you for your help and offers their assistance if you ever need it in the future.

 "One more thing," they say before you leave. "What Korin said about Tanner still isn't sitting right. Come with me. We should tie up one last loose end."

The detective cuffs a defiant Rex Korin, and together, you lead him through non-trafficked maintenance corridors towards the LA Aerostat. Ignoring his insults on the way, you're faced with the uncanny feeling that this is something the detective has done before.

You reach an abandoned garbage airlock, and it's only then Rex drops his tough guy act. Against his pleas, you stuff him inside. There's a brief moment when you wonder who will open the trap door on the other side. You suddenly realize it doesn't matter. You press the button to open the floor, and the arrogant accomplice to murder disappears through Venus's sulfurous, caustic fog.

The detective turns to you with a look in their eyes you've never seen before.

"You're mine now," they say. "Forever. Whatever I ask of you. No questions. When I say jump, you say how high. And if you ever speak of this to anyone, you'll find yourself begging for the mercy we just showed that scumbag."

 Lastly, you'll need this. For when shit hits the fan."

The detective hands you a briefcase. You're surprised by how heavy it is and wonder what could possibly be inside.

"First order of business: what was said about the cloaked figure reminds me of something Josephus Tanner told me about when he was at his worst. Come with me."
XXX

The detective is silent as you follow them down increasingly shabby corridors deep in the Encantado favelas. Far from the bright and airy world of the aerostat in the upper levels, the world you find yourself in now is dim, the air fouled by the aroma of industries most Venusians pretend don't exist: the acrid tang of formaldehyde in the morgue, earthy notes from food processing plants, all of it laced with sickly sulfurous tones emanating from nearby waste processing facilities. 

The journey terminates in front of a huge red door in what appears to be a warehouse repurposed for illegal housing. The detective approaches the keypad and pauses.

"I wish I could tell you what we're in for, but the truth is I have no idea," they say."Tanner started in the deep end with the handprint murders, and only fell deeper after getting involved with Miss M. He kept saying there was a danger he could never share. Brace yourself."

You enter the space and learn that if Josephus Tanner was once a respected law enforcement officer his home makes it clear he's since fallen far from grace. The walls are invisible behind stacks of boxes overflowing with papers and data files. The ground is littered with discarded take out cartons. A shabby sleeping sack is bundled in one corner.

The filth is ringed around three huge boards festooned with photographs and paraphernalia connected by a crazed web of red string. Before the board stands a hunched black form leaking shadows from its edges. The air around it dances with tongues of black flame. You watch as the form plucks a photograph like a ripe fruit, examines it, then sets it ablaze with a dark and smokeless fire.

"Police! Hands behind your head," shouts the detective before drawing their weapon. In an instant the form blinks a hundred and eighty degrees and freezes as still as a photograph. A pale face sits atop the creature and stares through you with enormous hollow eyes. Your entire body goes cold and you are unable to move. Your vision blurs and in a second instant the form is gone, leaving behind it nothing but the distinct odor of burned carbon. 

On closer inspection the board reveals a nearly incomprehensible conspiracy stretching across the entire system over decades. Just when the story seems to coalesce there are pieces missing, some leaving behind charred remains. The longer you stare at the story the less sense it seems to make. Two names stand out, however: Ursula and Philip.

When you finally tear yourself away from the board you see the detective standing in a dark corner above a filthy cot surrounded by jars of various fluids. The body on the makeshift bed is in the fetal position, turned away from you, its pale lower back exposed.

A black bruise stares up at you from Josephus Tanner's long dead body. It is in the shape of a long fingered hand.

The detective turns to you with a grim expression, their eyes welling up with tears.

"I have no idea what Tanner was looking into here. But it was dangerous. And that…thing we just saw? I never want to see anything like it again. I don't know how you feel about it but I suggest we bury this. All of it. It's the only way I'd feel safe."

You scrub the warehouse of all traces of Tanner's work. The detective places their former partner's body on a dolly and carts it to a nearby industrial district. With that grim work out of mind, you dismantle Tanner's evidence board without another thought of what story it might tell. You pile it on a second dolly and meet the detective at an incinerator.

Together you shovel Tanner's obsession onto the blazing pyre where it disappears alongside his body. You shake the detective's hand and part ways, knowing that you'll never speak of this to them, or anyone, ever again.

Your life moves forward accompanied by a strange sense that you're being watched. No matter what you do, you can't shake the feeling that one day the story you destroyed will catch up with you. That you'll be asked to return to it, and that you won't have the bravery to refuse.

Ignoring the detective's pleas you dismantle Tanner's conspiracy board and pile the remaining documents into boxes. You collate them as best you can, but the truth is that it is impossible to make sense of sprawling narrative, especially with vital pieces missing or partially burned. But you know someone who can. 

The journalist is surprised to see you given that they were a prime suspect in M's murder. But even if you can't fully trust them, you both understand nobody else in the system has the skills and knowledge to understand the story Tanner was trying to tell. You leave the boxes with them, along with all your hope that anyone will ever know why Middlemist died the way she did.

Over the next few days the journalist releases a slow trickle of news about what are now dubbed The Tanner Files. Based on what you read in those articles, you know it will take months, even years before anything has the chance of making sense.

Soon after you receive another strange message from Ursula. She thanks you for your work on the case, and tells you that you now play a part in something bigger than yourself. The message ends with a cryptic note that you'll be hearing from her again.

Time to get back to work.
